title: How does a philosophical mind work? - Quora

response.answer_text: thinking philosophically is a moment. there is no ‘philosophical mind’. the idea that philosophers exhale ‘wisdom’ is a folk superstition. given the sentence, “He intuited the solution.” you’d look first at the word ‘intuited’ and ask if there is really something called ‘intuition’. three months of study later you may have for yourself a better understanding of this word. and, may see that it has only a popular meaning and no meaning in reality. in the course of your study you’d have also looked at this word ‘solution’ to see if the concept was cosmically connected to reality, or if it was simply a tool-word to collapse several concepts into a dialog. having this thought about ‘intuition’ you’d only hold it for your personal and working knowledge. no one else would be able to understand your reasoning over this, and they’d think you were just playing with words. they’d never think you had any wisdom to give them… nothing like, ‘intuition lifts you to other realities.’ being philosophical is to dissolve opinions, not make them.

I can only speak for myself :) Philosophy is literally a “love of wisdom”. As such, it requires curiosity, a willingness to question assumed facts, and explore new thoughts and areas of knowledge. I do not subscribe to dogmatic philosophical concepts. Wisdom is stated in every(?) philosophic, theological, and scientific discipline. I think that philosophy is holistic and involves the whole of life. I use “life” in its’ most expansive and sometimes esoteric meaning.

I see an apple. What is the history of the apple? Was it always like this down a long line of ancestors? Of course not. It evolved, there is ample evidence of it. However, how could we know? We can explore the artwork of past generations, to find out how selective breeding changed how the apple looks. Why we went for what we go for largely depends on human tastes, and since human beings evolve much more slowly than an apple, we can assume the remained relatively constant. In this case, an apple today may have tasted just as delicious to someone in the past if we created a wormhole and passed it back to them. In that case, wouldn’t they plant the seeds and have a head-start? What would that do to the apples we see today? Would they be even more sweet and tasty looking? Given that time travel is only science fiction at this point in time and there is no evidence that it will ever cease to be so just yet, especially with all the paradoxes and investigation into the nature of time as an abstraction. I’m going to eat that apple now.
